data.title: DEATH OF VICTOR EMMANUEL.
data.meta_description: Victor E[?] II., King of Italy, is dead During three days be suffered from fever; and all the aid which c[?] he rendered by his physicians proved unavailing. The surgeons ...
data.text:
Victor lvi'iii.liiuel It., King of Italy, is dead.

Pining tlii.ee d.iys he suffered from fever ; and

all the :iid which could he rendered by his physicians

proved unavailing. The surgeons perfoimed

the operation of blood-lettinir. His

iVIajesty received the last Sacrament. Ilis Holiness

the Pope sent two Chamberlains with a

I'apal benediction, and stating that had it not

been for his own illness he would have gone him-

»;lf to visit the Kiujr.

A general mourning has been proclaimed

throughout llaly.

Prince Huruoert has heen proclaimed.

Some uneasiness is felt in coiiseouencc of the

belief that the newly proclaimed monarch entertains

very different political opinions from those

which were held by the late King of Italy.

The following is from AI en of the Time :—

1 1 Victor Emmanuel, King of Italy, son of

Charles Albert, King of Sardinia, and of Queen

Theresa, daughter of Grand Duke Ferdinand of

Tuscany, was horn March 14, 1820, and received

at his baptism the names Marie-Alhert-Eugene-

Ferilinand-Thoinas-Victor-Emmanuel. He was

carefully educated in science and military tactics,

and married in April 12, 1842. the Archduchess

Adelaide of Austria, who died January 20. 18.55.

He took an active part, as Duke of Savoy, in the

events of 1848, accompanying his father to the

field, and- behaving with great bravery at the

battles of Goi'to and ^iovara. On the evening

after the latter (March 24,1849), Charles Albert

signed his abdication in the Bellini Palace.

Little was then known of his sou and successor,

who assumed the title Victor Emmanuel II., except

that he was a dashing hunter, somewhat

haughty, and a reputed opponent of Liberalism.

He succeeded in obtaining from Austria terms

less humiliating than those imposed on hia father,

but the treaty of peace was not signed till August,

1849. On mountiug the throne of Sardinia he

endeavoured to reorganise the finances, the

armv, and the system of public instruction, concluded

with England several treaties ot commerce,

established railways, and promoted free

trade. He indignantly refused the offer made

by Austria for the cession of Parma, provided he

would abolish the Constitution. Genoa having

revolted, and expelled Ilia garrison, lie sent an

army against it, recovered his former rights, and

his efforts for the prosperity of his kingdom were

generally successful, lie had, however, one

great struggle throughout his rein with the court

and clnrgy of Rome. Guided by Ccunt Oavour,

he confiscated much church property, and took

away many clerical privileges. He concluded in

January, 1855, a convention with France and

England, to take part in the war against Russia,

and despatched to the Crimea an army of 17,000

men, under General I>e La Marmora, which distinguished

itself by a victory on the banks of the

Tchernaya. Sardinia took part in the Confer-
